title: Boots of Mobility: Don't Disable Them When Attacking a Ward
body:
I'm basically just asking the community if they think this would be nice to have. It sucks clearing wards as a Support and you lose all of your mobility for it.

Attacking puts you into combat (which disables the move speed bonus), but I'm sure it could be coded in to avoid that.

{{item:3117}}

Edit: Thanks for all the comments, even those that disagreed with the proposal. Get those Pool Party games in so we can unlock all the extras! [](http://i.ytimg.com/vi/WMXcN7S8gV0/hqdefault.jpg)

Too much map control if supports can roam at high speeds while clearing wards.
It punishes you for doing your job...

Vision control is not the supports job. It is a team effort. It should be a team effort to take control of it. Not a one man ward destroying army running around faster than anyone can stop them. 

Clearing wards is meant to have a risk involved.

Since when does having Mobi speed mean there's no risk? Any damage stops them, and most supports have a very slow attack speed which means literally every other person kills them faster, and they usually don't have Mobis either so they have a better chance of escaping too.
Having 60 more MS than everyone else makes clearing wards a lot safer unless you stand still while doing it.

Your point is that being safer is unfair yes?

So by that logic the fact that losing your entire bonus and being worse off than everyone else is fair?

Would you consider a compromise? Such as the bonus reduces to +45 to be equal to the other boots.

My point isn't to make Mobi's give an unfair advantage, but to get rid of their crippling disadvantage in only a single scenario (that being when you hit a ward and aren't in combat in any other way).
No it makes you vulnerable while clearing out enemy wards while removing your ms bonus making you easily caught out in enemy territory if you have poor vision control.

Most of the people voting "yes", do not understand the mechanics behind vision/map control and ward defense.  

With every risk needs to be reward: You are sacrificing your speed boost from mobis to clear a ward, which effectively knocks out a large portion of vision given to your enemies.  Having so much mobility while clearing wards, prevents your enemies from effectively defending their wards.
I see it from the junglers perspective, where you lose raptor buff to the ward, but if you want to gank effectively, you cant stop for it because you'll lose the speed buff.

What if instead of making them visible. It just disables the first ward you run into (giving the same ripple effect to show you're near the disabled ward). 

Opens up ganks without making the counter-vision power too strong. 

The ward will be disabled for 15s. Enough time that if staying could mean death. Even if you walk away and return you still wont know. This also gives the jungle enough time to try and find the ward and clear it while they gain no vision from it. 

A jungler could even take this to the next level if they know the wards timer. They could show up 30s before it's going to fade. The target could think it faded. Then head to re-ward, only to find a death timer.

.>Place ward on raptors
.>Jungler can't gain raptor buff for 3 minutes

Your suggested change forces the jungler to get {{item:3341}} if he wants to make use of the raptor buff. When he tries to gank, the enemy will still be alerted by the sudden loss of vision.

That's no different than how it is now. Difference is that this gives them the ability to play around the wards. It's more like a cloak to help ganking.

As the guy I replied too said. You're often forced to chose between giving up on the gank and taking the 30g from the ward or try the gank anyway. It's also very iffy as a buff. 

- Low MMR - Players probably didn't ward anyway.
- Medium MMR - Probably when it's most effective. Wards are more often enough though their attention to the map isn't as strong in case it gets cleared. 
- High MMR - Players know how to work around the jungler and the jungler mainly uses it to know if there is a ward so the gank is doable more than making the gank possible. 

I just don't think it works that great. Lower players don't really effect it much. Middle players use it the best because they're not all that great yet. Higher up players mostly use it as a "can I gank" check than making the gank possible. 

With all of this in mind. We could give a really good buff to Poachers Knife, additional smite effects if it kills the target(or if it just dies by your team). Because it needs something.

Blue Buff - 100% mana regen for 2 minutes, 3 minutes if jungle item is enchanted.
Red Buff - 100% health regen for 2 minutes, 3 minutes if jungle item is enchanted.
Golem - 25% tenacity for 1 minute, 2 minutes if jungle item enchanted.
Razerbeaks - Cloaking a ward also grants true sight to nearby objects and champions. 
Wolves - Next 3 basic attacks on monsters will critically strike. 30s duration
Gromp - Reflected damage vs monsters restores a % of the damage dealt as mana. Nothing too major though. 
Crab - 60% MS boost for 3s, boost falls off over it's duration. 
Dragon - Triples the bonus gold(25->75). 
Baron - Restores 15% of your missing health over 10 seconds.

As a "can I gank?" check, it's pretty darned useful! If there does happen to be a ward there, clearing it isn't a bad option. You distract the enemy laner, maybe their jungler too, get some gold. And then you can either turn around and go back to your jungle or camp to see if the laner _assumes_ that you've just gone back to your own jungle.

I think it would be fine if champions like Leona, who rely on being able to close in to make the most of their engagement tools, wouldn't be a bit too speedy while they roam about clearing wards and attempting to catch people. Granted, I don't play much Summoner's Rift, so I may just be speaking from the experience of the one normal I played on Rift as Leona this season, lol. Maybe halve the bonus speed while you're actively attacking it, then restore it to full immediately if you successfully clear the ward/assist a teammate in doing so.
